title: rclone serve s3: invalid error response when using wrong password
body: **rclone serve s3** can't handle invalid credentials very well: 1. Open a terminal and run `rclone server s3` (in my case, I use a container): ```bash $ podman run --rm --env=RCLONE_ADDR=:8080 --env=RCLONE_AUTH_KEY=admin,admin --publish=8080:8080 --volume=/tmp/data:/data docker.io/rclone/rclone:1.66 serve s3 /data ``` 2. Open a 2nd terminal and run a simple request with rclone as a client (the password is wrong on purpose): ```bash $ RCLONE_S3_ENDPOINT=http://localhost:8080 RCLONE_S3_ACCESS_KEY_ID=admin RCLONE_S3_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=admin2 ./rclone lsf -vv s3: ``` `/home/tony/.config/rclone/rclone.conf`: ``` [s3] type = s3 provider = Other env_auth = true ``` 4. ```bash $ ./rclone --version rclone v1.66.0 - os/version: debian 12.1 (64 bit) - os/kernel: 6.1.0-18-amd64 (x86_64) - os/type: linux - os/arch: amd64 - go/version: go1.22.1 - go/linking: static - go/tags: none ``` Since I use rclone a lot as S3 client and never had such problems, I suspect, that `rclone serve s3` might not be fully complient to the S3 specification (yet) and sends an invalid error response. According to [Amazon's S3 documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/ErrorResponses.html), such responses should look like this: ```xml [...] ``` ... but apparently the response sent by `rclone serve s3`, looks like this: ```xml [...] ``` I also suspect that the rclone S3 client doesn't expect such a response and tries again and again for about a minute until it finally fails. I wouldn't be surprised, if such invalid error responses might happen for other errors as well. EDIT: I'm also not sure that this message is the best way to tell the client that the password is wrong: "_The request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided. Check your key and signing method._"
